head.title: SUNDAY, September 11, 1994; Pop! Go the Coal Fumes

identified-content.org: BELLINGHAM CARBON DIOXIDE RECOVERY FACILITY (BELLINGHAM, MASS)

hedline.hl1: SUNDAY, September 11, 1994; Pop! Go the Coal Fumes

block.p: Everyone is used to drinking soda in recycled cans and bottles. But who knew that the fizz in soda pop was often recycled too?

The Bellingham Carbon Dioxide Recovery Facility, in Bellingham, Mass., strips CO2 from the fumes belched from a local coal-based power plant. The facility channels the toxic flue gases into a filtering system that gleans 99.99 percent pure carbon dioxide, which is then liquefied and sold to the food-service industry.
Everyone is used to drinking soda in recycled cans and bottles. But who knew that the fizz in soda pop was often recycled too?

The Bellingham Carbon Dioxide Recovery Facility, in Bellingham, Mass., strips CO2 from the fumes belched from a local coal-based power plant. The facility channels the toxic flue gases into a filtering system that gleans 99.99 percent pure carbon dioxide, which is then liquefied and sold to the food-service industry.

The coal-to-cola process has received little fanfare, but independent bottlers for Coca-Cola and other companies in the Northeast use substantial amounts of the manufactured fizz. In other parts of the country, CO2 is mined as a different sort of "natural" gas.
